title: Nice new cinematic, Riot. You hired the guys behind Legend of Korra?

embed.description: When Runeterra's sacred treasures are misused, the Wandering Caretaker intervenes.

body:
Good choice. Very good choice.

By the way, have you thought to make a compilation of anime shorts ala The Animatrix? I guarantee you that'd sell well, especially if you got it on the iTunes store or Netflix.

replies.body: It's from the same animators of "Warriors" and the Rek'sai teaser
I'm guessing they also are the guys behind Legend of Korra.
Actually, Warriors and the Rek'sai teaser were done by different animation studios. We did work with Studio Mir on this piece, who we also collaborated with for the Road to the Cup video.
I knew there was a reason I loved the animation style in this vid. It's beautiful. Sad it's still so cryptic though. Maybe one day we can have nice things.
How in any stretch of the imagination is this not a nice thing?
It's an entire three minute video, presumably quite expensive, just to show off Bard instead of actually telling an interesting story?
It's storytelling. Not very descriptive storytelling, but it is telling a story.

Those pesky Noxians...

you rioters, trolling lore lovers every time you can...

At least this time was actually lore XD

Where?  

Bard keeps track of powerful relics.

Bard did a thing when a human used a thing when his village was attacked.

That's basically all that we got from this video lore wise
It does tell us that Bard doesn't actually care about humans. He inteferes for harmony, not to save anyone. That is something.
Still, stuff happened. That's basically lore no matter how small.
I'd like to see more of this type of presentation instead of stuff like the Amumu video or the Rek'sai short.

> [{quoted}](name=Sharjo,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=a2AFr68a,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-03-05T19:56:01.334+0000)
>
> So from what I understand or at least my interpretation of events is the following;
> 
> Noxian Soldiers (maybe) invade the lands of the Bards, which is probably in Ionia. They were sent to take the ancient relics that reside there. Bard senses when the power is used and immediately guesses something's wrong. He appears and uses his power to whisk away the relics, taking them to someplace beyond the mortal plane.
> 
> I suppose this gives insight on to why Noxus invaded Ionia without a League to intervene; Boram wanted Ionia's ancient secrets for some reason.

Boram ? You mean Swain right ?

No Boram. While stuff's in flux at the moment Noxus originally invaded Ionia...what 19 years ago now? Boram was still Grand General at the time. Makes you wonder what Boram was hoping to find in Ionia, and why he needed it in the first place.
Pretty sure Sion is there! (Guy with the axe)
Nah Sion's been an abomination for centuries. This is a modern occurrence, or at-least within the last two decades.

I'm thinking this is telling the story of (or is a retelling of) an event that happened in the history of Ionia?  Because the Wonder Above teaser site talked about the arrival of the constellation, and as such, implies that the teaser site is a moment at least a significant amount of time after the video.

[http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/champion-preview/wonder-above](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/champion-preview/wonder-above)

The people around the campfire might be the survivors - or the descendants of the survivors - maybe it wasn't a complete massacre after all?  They don't seem to be holding a grudge against Bard, either way.

Thoughts?

In my mind, we are seeing one portion of Ionia's invasion by Noxus, possibly even the reason for it. Assaulting a peaceful nation, an easier conquest with substantially less risk, overflowing with untapped resources is another means of propagating future aggression.

Bard is intervening on behalf of the Stone, which has quite a cosmic appearance, not the people.

> [{quoted}](name=Bioluminescence,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=a2AFr68a,comment-id=000f,timestamp=2015-03-05T22:33:45.995+0000)

Because the Wonder Above teaser site talked about the arrival of the constellation, and as such, implies that the teaser site is a moment at least a significant amount of time after the video.
> 
> [http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/champion-preview/wonder-above](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/champion-preview/wonder-above)

The problem with these events being separated by a great deal of time is that at the end of this video is when the constellation appears.

To quote the fellow in "The Wonder Above":

> There was a time, not long ago, when this constellation was absent from the night sky. 

Implying that it disappeared in the first place. Potentially, even those this is conjecture, Bard's constellation disappeared not too long after he left with the relic and the shrines, signalling he had left the physical plane of Runterra. The constellation has become apparent again as a signal of his impending return. Perhaps the star signs "appear" more strongly and "disappear" all together in correspondence to when things art happening in regards to them; Bard just left Runeterra; the constellation sparkles like a firework display, and then disappears afterwards, kinda like a natural omen. 

Also by appear and disappear I don't mean stars just up and vanishing, but more like the constellations being harder to spot and the stars that make them up being obstructed or dim.

I see things differently. When they state that the Bard constellation was absent not long ago; I think it means that it had never existed until recently. At the time of "The Wonder Above," those stargazers probably had grown accustomed to the twinkling constellation, it was ordinary for them. Maybe they had forgotten it's significance, maybe not. Perhaps it was a village Eldar who was reminding his youthful peers of the great cosmic change during his lifetime.
True.
The stone cut a mountain in half. A mountain.* In half*.
Seems the former Grand General was looking for some ancient weaponry from Ionia's most sacred places...
What better way to get an edge over Noxus' most persistent rival than plundering the forgotten treasures of a peaceful nation?
Nothing could possibly go wrong!

Surely {{champion:11}} such{{champion:39}} a{{champion:43}} complacent{{champion:64}} nation{{champion:103}} is{{champion:98}} devoid{{champion:84}} of{{champion:85}} warriors{{champion:110}} that{{champion:157}} could{{champion:238}} offer{{champion:134}} significant{{champion:16}} resistance{{champion:62}}.

http://i1.minus.com/ibde6IQQpKL5LM.jpg

Right?

*“Don't mistake my kindness for weakness. I am kind to everyone, but when someone is unkind to me, weak is not what you are going to remember about me.”* - Al Capone

Ionia confirmed American gangsters from Prohibition era.

Absoluetly!

I'm really looking forward to when Ionia kicks Noxus's arse, just saying.

report {{champion:122}} for feeding
It didn't even look like Darius. If anything, it looked like pre-death Sion.
But Sion died after killing Jarvan the 1st, didn't he? I know he was a tough guy, but I don't think he could come back from total obliteration like that.

I didn't say it *was* Sion, I said it *looked* like Sion.

Either way you slice it, it's obviously not Darius is the point I wanted to make.

> [{quoted}](name=a god damn hero,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=a2AFr68a,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2015-03-05T19:56:12.027+0000)

nawh dawg, darius just got a shave thats all.
Would make sense if anything about him looked remotely like Darius.
darius will have killed the old man before the dead ray appeared.

so the bard appeared just to summon Ao Shin?
because the old man said "we will die without him" and it was NOT talking about the bard.

I heard "they'll die without it"; I think he was just referring to the meeps and the stone, respectively

EDIT: Apparently the subtitle is "we'll die without it", which, based on other comments I've been reading (from reds and players alike), I guess the old man was more intent on the protection of his village than the protection of the artifact. My initial thought on what happened was the old man was moving the artifact to the top of the mountain where Bard would then pick it up and therefore it'd be safe, but with everything now taken into account, I would guess that the old man intended to use the stone at the top of the mountain to try to protect the village, where Bard didn't like the old man using it as a weapon and thus takes everything away.
pretty sure he said "we will die without it" meaning the stone/relic thing.
Subtitle say "We'll die....without it."

That makes sense. I figured he was referring to his people, who would not be able to survive the battle without the power the stone obviously carries. This makes me think that if Bard is a caretaker, he is not a caretaker of humans and their like. He's starting to seem like a real peachy kind of guy!

Bard also seemed to put himself in the sky via a constellation, in effect saving himself. That seems selfish to me, when he could be defending Ionia. 
Also, he does have that same beard-thing as ao shin, so maybe.

I'm wondering what Bard's intentions are. He seems to not really care about people much, just relics. It seems like he could have done something to save the people, but only intervened when the orb was threatened...but if he had saved the people the orb wouldn't have been threatened.

The old man cut the mountain in order to save himself from the Noxian Axeman which alerted Bard that powerful objects is not meant to be used by selfish beings. Humans are fools and will fight over it, so Bard took it from the old man and prevented it to be used. He cares for the balance of this world and not the people, otherwise he would be a generic good guy like most of the champions. 

If humans are destroyed, the world would know peace.

I interpreted it differently. The old man was trying to take the orb to the top of the mountain for Bard to pick it up. The tribe being attacked didn't use it to protect themselves. He used it out of desperation or accident. Bard noticed what was happening and picked it up himself rather than help the tribe not have to use the relic.

Just like how we don't give much shiet about ants, Bard as a demigod or a literal god, doesn't care about the lives of mortals either.

He doesn't seem to have nor understand mortal emotions and feelings though.

At least Bard is better than humans in a sense he works actively and religiously to preserve balance of power when it's threatened, essentially his personality is just like that of his appearance, he is a celestial robot.
